blocks.content: 1.2 Website Components: Frontend / Backend / Database / Hosting
A website is more than just what you see on the screen. Behind it, multiple parts work together. Let’s use an online bookstore as an example to explain the four main components step by step.
The frontend is what you see when you open a website, such as the book list, shopping cart button, or login form.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Display content and provide interactions (e.g., clicking “Add to Cart”).
🎨 **Analogy**: Like the storefront and interior design of a shop — the first thing users see.

blocks.content: When you click a button on the frontend, such as “Checkout,” the backend handles the logic behind the scenes.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Process user requests (e.g., calculate total price, verify login).
🍳 **Analogy**: Like a restaurant kitchen — the frontend takes the order, the backend does the cooking.

blocks.content: An online bookstore needs a place to record book information and user data — that’s the database.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Store and manage data (e.g., book titles, prices, user orders).
📦 **Analogy**: Like a warehouse, where all goods and records are stored.

blocks.content: Hosting is deploying your website to the Internet so anyone can access your online bookstore anytime.

items: 🔑 **Main Role**: Keep the website online 24/7 and handle traffic.
📚 **Platforms**: Free options include GitHub Pages, Netlify; professional options include AWS, Vercel.
🌍 **Analogy**: Like renting a shop on the street so anyone can walk in.

blocks.content:
Here’s a simple flow that can be shown with a diagram:

User → Frontend (browser interface) → Backend (logic processing) → Database (read/store data) → Hosting (public network service) → Return result to user screen

blocks.title: 📖 Summary
blocks.content:
👉 Frontend: What users see
👉 Backend: Logic and operations
👉 Database: Stores all data
👉 Hosting: Makes the site publicly accessible

These four parts work together to run an online bookstore:
User selects a book (Frontend) → System calculates the price (Backend) → Data is queried (Database) → Website is deployed for purchase (Hosting).
